content:
I am not sure if what I want makes sense, but what I want is a functor T:CJ→CT: \mathcal C^J → \mathcal CT:CJ→C that is a monad in every j∈Jj ∈ Jj∈J, with some magical compatibility conditions on top. In the case of J={⋆}J = \{⋆\}J={⋆}, this would simply be a monad. Can I generalize monads this way?

starting point 1: equations of monad

Here are the usual equations for the identity and composition of a monad ⟨T;η;μ⟩⟨T; η; μ⟩⟨T;η;μ⟩:

μ∘ηT=id⁡=μ∘Tη:T→Tμ∘μ=μ∘Tμ\begin {gather} μ ∘ ηT = \operatorname {id} = μ ∘ Tη: T → T \\ μ ∘ μ = μ ∘ Tμ \end {gather}μ∘ηT=id=μ∘Tη:T→Tμ∘μ=μ∘Tμ​​

starting point 2: identity and composition in operads

In an operad, we have arrows that look like XJ→XX^J → XXJ→X, and the definitions of identity and composition are suitably altered: composition takes one function «after» and JJJ functions *«before
»*. This is technical but straightforward and intuitive. The equations for the identity and composition in some operad O\mathcal OO look like so:

∀n∈N,f∈On∣id⁡∘∏i1f=f=f∘∏inid⁡∀n∈N,∀m∈Nnf∈On,g∈∏inOm(i)h∈∏in∏jm(i)Oj∣(f∘∏infi)∘∏in∏jm(i)hij=f∘∏in(gi∘∏jm(i)hij)\begin {align} \left . ∀ n ∈ ℕ, f ∈ \mathcal O_n \quad \right | \quad & \operatorname {id} ∘ \prod_i^1 f = f = f ∘ \prod_i^n \operatorname {id} \\ \left .{\begin {aligned} ∀ n ∈ ℕ, ∀ m ∈ ℕ^n \\ f ∈ \mathcal O_n, g ∈ \prod_i^n \mathcal O_{m (i)} \\ h ∈ \prod_i ^n \prod_j^{m(i)} \mathcal O_j \end {aligned}} \quad \right | \quad & \left (f ∘ \prod_i^n f_i \right ) ∘ \prod_i^n \prod_j^{m (i)} h_{ij} = f ∘ \prod_i^n \left (g_i ∘ \prod_j^{m (i)} h_{ij} \right ) \end {align}∀n∈N,f∈On​∣∀n∈N,∀m∈Nnf∈On​,g∈i∏n​Om(i)​h∈i∏n​j∏m(i)​Oj​​​​id∘i∏1​f=f=f∘i∏n​id(f∘i∏n​fi​)∘i∏n​j∏m(i)​hij​=f∘i∏n​​gi​∘j∏m(i)​hij​​​​

Here, the circle ∘∘∘ is a binary operator, and the id⁡\operatorname {id}id is a nullary operator.

synthesis: equations of monad in operad

I am now going to transplant the identity equation for operads to the setting of functor category. Let us denote the circle as μμμ and id⁡\operatorname {id}id as ηηη. Let us also denote the product big operator as TTT with suitable indexing attached. So, for example, Ti2η\mathop T _i^2 ηTi2​η would mean the product id⁡×id⁡\operatorname {id} × \operatorname {id}id×id. Then, we can write the same equations like this:

μ∘ηT=id⁡=μ∘Tinημ∘μ=μ∘Tinμ\begin {gather} μ ∘ η \mathop T = \operatorname {id} = μ ∘ \mathop T \limits_i^n η \\ μ ∘ μ = μ ∘ \mathop T \limits_i^n μ \end {gather}μ∘ηT=id=μ∘iTn​ημ∘μ=μ∘iTn​μ​​

Looks very similar to the usual equations for the identity and composition of monad! Although I see that this is a stretch. I want to believe!

example: the product co-monad

The example I have in mind is the product co-monad ⟨X;Y⟩↦X×Y⟨X; Y⟩ ↦ X × Y⟨X;Y⟩↦X×Y in sets, which is a monad in the opposite category. I am going to denote the arrows in the opposite category as reversed arrows ←←← and composition as circle with reversed arrow on top ∘←\overset ← ∘∘←. Now, product is a monad (in the opposite category) on either side already:

ηleft:X←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦xμleft:X×Y×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;y⟩\begin{gather} η_{\rm left}: X ← X × Y = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ x \\ μ_{\rm left}: X × Y × Y ← X × Y = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; y⟩ \end{gather}ηleft​:X←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦xμleft​:X×Y×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;y⟩​​

ηright:Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦yμright:X×X×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;⟨x;y⟩⟩\begin{gather} η_{\rm right}: Y ← X × Y = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ y \\ μ_{\rm right}: X × X × Y ← X × Y = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨x; ⟨x; y⟩⟩ \end{gather}ηright​:Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦yμright​:X×X×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;⟨x;y⟩⟩​​

However, we do not have a single unambiguous μμμ operation:

μleft∘←μright≠μright∘←μleftμ_{\rm left} \overset ← ∘ μ_{\rm right} ≠ μ_{\rm right} \overset ← ∘ μ_{\rm left}μleft​∘←μright​=μright​∘←μleft​

These compositions are not even unambiguous. For example, there are two ways to have μleft∘←μrightμ_{\rm left} \overset ← ∘ μ_{\rm right}μleft​∘←μright​:

μright∘←μleft,⟨X×X,Y⟩:X×X×Y×Y←X×X×Y←X×Yμright∘←μleft,⟨X,X×Y⟩:X×X×Y×X×Y←X×X×Y←X×Y\begin {align} μ_{\rm right} \overset ← ∘ μ_{{\rm left}, ⟨X × X, Y⟩}&: X × X × Y × Y ← X × X × Y ← X × Y \\ μ_{\rm right} \overset ← ∘ μ_{{\rm left}, ⟨X, X × Y⟩}&: X × X × Y × X × Y ← X × X × Y ← X × Y \end {align}μright​∘←μleft,⟨X×X,Y⟩​μright​∘←μleft,⟨X,X×Y⟩​​:X×X×Y×Y←X×X×Y←X×Y:X×X×Y×X×Y←X×X×Y←X×Y​​

What I imagine is that we should have a combined μμμ defined like so:

μ:X×Y×X×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩μ: X × Y × X × Y ← X × Y = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩μ:X×Y×X×Y←X×Y=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩

Now, we have the identity equations to verify:

μ∘←ηleftT=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦x)=id⁡μ∘←ηrightT=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦y)=id⁡μ∘←Ti{left;right}ηi=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←((⟨x;y⟩↦x)×(⟨x;y⟩↦y))=id⁡\begin {alignat*} {0} μ \overset ← ∘ η_{\rm left} \mathop T &= (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \overset ← ∘ (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ x) &= \operatorname {id} \\ μ \overset ← ∘ η_{\rm right} \mathop T &= (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \overset ← ∘ (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ y) &= \operatorname {id} \\ μ \overset ← ∘ \mathop T \limits_i^{\{{\rm left}; {\rm right}\}} η_i &= (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \overset ← ∘ ((⟨x; y⟩ ↦ x) × (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ y)) &= \operatorname {id} \end {alignat*}μ∘←ηleft​Tμ∘←ηright​Tμ∘←iT{left;right}​ηi​​=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦x)=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦y)=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←((⟨x;y⟩↦x)×(⟨x;y⟩↦y))​=id=id=id​

The equation for composition looks like so:

μ∘←μ=μ∘←Ti{left;right}μμ \overset ← ∘ μ = μ \overset ← ∘ \mathop T \limits_i^{\{{\rm left}; {\rm right}\}} μμ∘←μ=μ∘←iT{left;right}​μ

And it holds in our example:

(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;y;x;y;x;y;x;y⟩=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)×(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;y;x;y;x;y;x;y⟩\begin {alignat*} {0} (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \overset ← ∘ (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \\ = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨x; y; x; y; x; y; x; y⟩ \\ = \\ (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \overset ← ∘ (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) × (⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨x; y⟩; ⟨x; y⟩⟩) \\ = ⟨x; y⟩ ↦ ⟨x; y; x; y; x; y; x; y⟩ \end {alignat*}(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;y;x;y;x;y;x;y⟩=(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)∘←(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)×(⟨x;y⟩↦⟨⟨x;y⟩;⟨x;y⟩⟩)=⟨x;y⟩↦⟨x;y;x;y;x;y;x;y⟩​

So, it kind of seems that we have an example of what I wanted here.

my question

Is this thing a thing? Does it make sense?
Makes no sense at all?

Here's a vague thought:

If C↦CJ\mathcal{C} \mapsto \mathcal{C}^JC↦CJ is a pseudomonad on Cat, or can be made so when JJJ has enough structure, then the microcosm principle suggests that we might be able to define a kind of generalized monad T:CJ→CT: \mathcal{C}^J \to \mathcal{C}T:CJ→C "riding" this pseudomonad.

I could be mixed up, but this is how I would start.
What is the standard introduction to pseudomonads? Is it the same as 2-monads?

John Baez said:

Here's a vague thought:

If C↦CJ\mathcal{C} \mapsto \mathcal{C}^JC↦CJ is a pseudomonad on Cat, or can be made so when JJJ has enough structure, then the microcosm principle suggests that we might be able to define a kind of generalized monad T:CJ→CT: \mathcal{C}^J \to \mathcal{C}T:CJ→C "riding" this pseudomonad.

I could be mixed up, but this is how I would start.

"Raising to a comonoid object" is always a monad, and every JJJ in a Cartesian category is a comonoid (even in a canonical way); so [J,−][J,-][J,−] is a monad. JJJ can be a discrete category, or even a nondiscrete one
if JJJ is a monoid, on the other hand, raising to JJJ is a comonad, and T:CJ→CT : C^J \to CT:CJ→C is an arrow in its coKleisli category.

If (J,−⊗−,i)(J, -\otimes-, i)(J,−⊗−,i) is a strict monoidal category, it would seem that you could define some kind of monad-like structure on a functor T ⁣:CJ→CT\colon \mathcal{C}^J \to \mathcal{C}T:CJ→C with multiplication of type

μ ⁣:T∘(TJ)∘C−⊗−⇒T\mu\colon T \circ (T^J) \circ \mathcal{C}^{-\otimes-} \Rightarrow Tμ:T∘(TJ)∘C−⊗−⇒T

and unit of type

η ⁣:Ci⇒T\eta\colon \mathcal{C}^i \Rightarrow Tη:Ci⇒T

which reduces to a usual monad when JJJ is the terminal category with its unique monoidal structure.
Not sure what this is.

So in the case of JJJ monoid, the correct axioms for your T to be a monad-like gadget are precisely the monad axioms for the coKleisli endo-morphism T♯:C⇝CT^\sharp : C \rightsquigarrow CT♯:C⇝C that T defines.
...Probably exactly what Fosco is saying :)
Yeah, I expect unwinding my definition one gets Amar's maps
(probably my more intrinsic description makes it easier to pass from strict monoids to pseudomonoids, probably not? Anyway, it's a potato-pseudopotayto situation)
Is there any possibility for a more accessible explanation? I have no idea what «raising to a comonoid object» means, and from then on it is an uphill battle for me.
It's simply the functor C↦CJC\mapsto C^JC↦CJ
IIUC for you JJJ is a set?
so CJ=∏j∈JCC^J = \prod_{j\in J} CCJ=∏j∈J​C is a product of ∣J∣|J|∣J∣ copies of C; legitimately called "C to the J"
So, your CCC is an object of some ambient category? And C↦CJC ↦ C^JC↦CJ is the action on objects of an exponential functor?
We are taking specifically the exponential functor in Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat seen as a cartesian closed category.
by extension, more generally, if JJJ is a category, CJC^JCJ is the category of functors J→CJ\to CJ→C; this more general description matches the case when JJJ is discrete

Ignat Insarov said:

So, your CCC is an object of some ambient category? And C↦CJC ↦ C^JC↦CJ is the action on objects of an exponential functor?

CCC is a category; the functor (−)J(-)^J(−)J is an endofunctor of the category of categories.
So CCC is a category seen as an object in a category of categories, alright!
So we want JJJ to be a monoidal category, right? But discrete categories are not usually monoidal, right? So this construction cannot be done when JJJ is a non-trivial set.
So in particular this would not explain my product example.
Right?

Ignat Insarov said:

So, your CCC is an object of some ambient category? 

His CCC is your C\mathcal{C}C. Not all of us us can afford fancy fonts. :wink:

Ignat Insarov said:

So we want JJJ to be a monoidal category, right? But discrete categories are not usually monoidal, right? So this construction cannot be done when JJJ is a non-trivial set.

(Small) discrete monoidal categories are the same as monoid structures on the set of objects...
So there is plenty of them

Just in case anyone is having trouble following this conversation: I think Fosco solved @Ignat Insarov's original problem of defining a nice kind of generalized monad that looks like T:CJ→CT: \mathcal{C}^J \to \mathcal{C}T:CJ→C.

fosco said:

if JJJ is a monoid, on the other hand, raising to JJJ is a comonad, and T:CJ→CT : C^J \to CT:CJ→C is an arrow [indeed an endomorphism] in its coKleisli category.

So in the case of JJJ monoid, the correct axioms for your TTT to be a monad-like gadget are precisely the monad axioms for the coKleisli endo-morphism T♯:C⇝CT^\sharp : C \rightsquigarrow CT♯:C⇝C that T defines.

Alright! It makes some sense now. But there is still something I do not understand…

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

μ ⁣:T∘(TJ)∘C−⊗−⇒T\mu\colon T \circ (T^J) \circ \mathcal{C}^{-\otimes-} \Rightarrow Tμ:T∘(TJ)∘C−⊗−⇒T

What is this C−⊗−\mathcal C^{-⊗-}C−⊗− here? Does it go like CJ⟶C−⊗−(CJ)J\mathcal C^J \overset {\mathcal C^{-⊗-}} \longrightarrow \mathcal (C^J)^JCJ⟶C−⊗−​(CJ)J?

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

η ⁣:Ci⇒T\eta\colon \mathcal{C}^i \Rightarrow Tη:Ci⇒T

And what is the index iii doing here? Is it i∈Ji ∈ Ji∈J? Do we have JJJ different ηηη's then?

Yes, sorry: I am seing −⊗−- \otimes -−⊗− as a functor J×J→JJ \times J \to JJ×J→J, so that C−⊗−\mathcal{C}^{- \otimes -}C−⊗− goes from CJ\mathcal{C}^JCJ to CJ×J≃(CJ)J\mathcal{C}^{J \times J} \simeq (\mathcal{C}^J)^JCJ×J≃(CJ)J; and iii as the functor 1→J1 \to J1→J picking the unit object iii (here 111 is the terminal category), so Ci\mathcal{C}^iCi goes from CJ\mathcal{C}^JCJ to C1≃C\mathcal{C}^1 \simeq \mathcal{C}C1≃C.

Alright, this makes sense syntactically! I need some time to figure out if it does what I want, though. In my example of the product co-monad (that I guess was so messed up that no one could understand what I tried to say), I figured I need two different ηηη's, and my index set J={left;right}J = \{{\rm left};{\rm right}\}J={left;right} is not equipped with any monoidal structure.

Maybe, maybe, maybe you can find some interest in this presentation with regard to your question. I'm not sure but I'll post it in case! (To start with, I'm not even sure to understand what you want. What "a functor T:CJ→CT:\mathcal{C}^J \rightarrow \mathcal{C}T:CJ→C which is a monad in every j∈Jj \in Jj∈J is supposed to mean precisely?")

For every Set\mathbf{Set}Set-operad O\mathcal{O}O, a notion that is called a "O\mathcal{O}O-category" is defined. This a category with a bunch of functors Cn→C\mathcal{C}^n \rightarrow \mathcal{C}Cn→C for various integers nnn, multiplication operations and a unit operations. The various integers nnn depend on the choice of the operad O\mathcal{O}O

For some choice of O\mathcal{O}O it gives exactly a monad on C\mathcal{C}C. For some other choice of O\mathcal{O}O it gives exactly a structure of lax monoidal category on C\mathcal{C}C. And of course for other operads, it gives yet other categorical structures.

And then you can also define algebras over a O\mathcal{O}O-category and you recover algebras over a monad and monoid in a lax monoidal category for some choices of O\mathcal{O}O.

Maybe you can specialize to the cases where there is just one functor Cn→C\mathcal{C}^n \rightarrow \mathcal{C}Cn→C for some choice of operad O\mathcal{O}O and maybe you can generalize from nnn to an arbitrary set III by tweaking the definition to get something as you want, I don't know.
I don't even remember precisely this idea but hopefully I wrote something about it at the time when it was in my head!

There is an old discussion relating Jean-Baptiste Vienney's O\mathcal{O}O-categories at #theory: category theory > (ID my structure) operad in a monoidal bicategory, some of which might or might not be relevant, I don't know.
My old work with James Dolan on coherent O-algebras is also somewhat relevant.
It will take me some time to look into all these things…
